Boarding or rooming house: A building dedicated to and used for the lodging and/or feeding, for compensation, of three or more non-transient, persons of separate families as defined herein. Boarding or rooming house shall be synonymous with the term "bed and breakfast establishment". Body shop: A building or location where motor vehicle repair and/or replacement is performed, including, but not limited to, painting and metal fabrication of motor vehicle bodies or structures. A body shop is a major automotive service. Buffer: An area of a lot established and maintained to create an open and neutral space between properties with different and possible incompatible types of use, and it is measured from the common property line of the different uses. Buildable area: The portion of a lot remaining after required yards have been provided. Building: Any structure attached to the ground which has a roof and which is designed for the shelter, housing or enclosure of persons, animals or property of any kind. Building administrator: The official designated by the city council as being responsible for issuing construction permits and certificates of occupancy. Building, height of: The vertical distance measured from average elevation of the proposed finished grade to the highest point of the coping of a flat roof or to the deck line of a mansard roof, or to the average height of the highest gable of a pitch or hip roof. Building, principal: A building or structure in which is conducted the principal use of the lot on which said building is situated. Care home: An orphanage, rest home, nursing home, convalescent home, boarding home for the aged or similar use established to render domiciliary care, but not including facilities for the care of mental patients, alcoholics, drug addicts and nursery schools. Carport: Shall mean a covered structure used for housing at least two vehicles and has the following minimum dimensions: vehicular entrance height, eight feet; interior height, eight feet; vehicular entrance width, 16 feet; and overall garage width and depth, 24 feet. The floor shall be constructed of concrete or asphalt. If fully or partially enclosed, the floor shall be concrete. Concrete floors shall be reinforced, where appropriate, and a minimum of four inches in thickness with appropriate fill and base. Asphalt floors shall be a minimum of two-inch type "E" or "F" asphalt topping, binder and four inches of graded aggregate base. Where carports are constructed, such structures shall not be enclosed for living space, storage purposes or any other purpose without first obtaining an administrative variance from the city. In addition to all other requirements for an administrative variance under this chapter, applicants must also meet the following requirements: (1) Where applicable, applicants must obtain the prior written approval of their homeowner's association, certifying that the enclosure complies with all terms, conditions and restrictions contained in their neighborhood covenants (CCR's). A copy of this written approval must be submitted along with the application for administrative variance. Applications submitted without this approval will not be accepted. (2) All applications for an administrative variance to construct an enclosed carport must be presented to the city for prior review and approval. (3) The applicant must submit plans and pictures to the city illustrating the proposed enclosure. (4) If the application for administrative variance is approved by the city, the applicant must next obtain all appropriate permits from the city's building department. (5) The final enclosed carport must be inspected by the city's building inspector, and a certificate of occupancy must be issued. (6) Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, no administrative variance to construct an enclosed carport will be issued where the applicant will not have adequate parking remaining after the enclosure. The decision of what constitutes adequate parking shall be in the sole discretion of the city. Central sanitary sewer systems: Collection, transportation and treatment of sanitary sewerage, via a pipe network, to a common collection point as required by the Department of Natural Resources for the State of Georgia. Certificate of occupancy: A document issued by the building administrator or designee indicating the use of a particular building or land conforms with the requirements of this chapter or that there has been a variance therefrom granted. Church or other place of worship: A building used for public worship including temples, synagogues and related Sunday school or church school facilities. City: Shall mean the City of Hampton or its designee. City public street: A road, public street, or other public right-of-way that is owned and/or maintained by the city. Clinic: An establishment where patients, who are not lodged overnight, are admitted for examination and treatment by one physician or dentist or a group of physicians or dentists practicing medicine. Club: A building or facilities owned or operated by and for special educational or recreational purposes, but not primarily for profit or to render a service that is customarily carried on for gain. Cluster housing: A residential development which provides for the grouping of attached and/or detached single-family dwellings on lots that may be smaller than normally permitted in a certain zoning district for purposes of preserving open space and natural features of the terrain thereby allowing public facilities and services to be provided for more economically. Commercial vehicle: A vehicle whose gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) is over 26,000 pounds, or a trailer with a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of over 10,000 pounds, including commercial tractor-trailers, dump trucks, wreckers, and earth-moving equipment. Agricultural vehicles and equipment and school buses shall be excluded from this definition. Conditional exception: A use within a certain zoning district which is not permitted as a matter of right, but may be permitted within the district upon approval by the city council. A conditional exception is temporary and limited to one year. Conditional use: A use within certain zoning districts of this chapter which is not permitted as a matter of right, but may be permitted within these districts by the city council. A conditional use is permanent in nature. Council: The Mayor and City Council of the City of Hampton, Georgia. The word "council" is synonymous with "city council." County: Shall mean Henry County or its designee. County public street: A road, street or other public right-of-way which is owned and/or maintained by Henry County. Curb cut: The providing of vehicular ingress and/or egress between property and an abutting public street. Density: The number of dwelling units per acre of land used for residential, commercial or industrial purposes. Unless otherwise specified, density figures are to be set forth in terms of net acres or the amount of land devoted to residential, commercial or industrial use exclusive of public streets or other public lands. Drive-in: A retail or service enterprise wherein service is provided to the customer on the outside of the principal building. Drive-in restaurant: Any place or premises used for sale, dispensing or servicing of food, refreshment or beverages in automobiles or other vehicles, including those establishments where customers may consume same on the premises. Dwelling: A building or portion thereof which is designed or used exclusively for residential purposes, including single-family, two-family, multiple-family dwellings, rooming and boarding houses, fraternities, sororities and modular dwellings, but not including hotels or motels. Dwelling, condominium: The ownership in fee simple title of a single unit in a multi-unit structure and an undivided ownership interest, in common with other owners of the common elements of the structure, including the common areas of land and its appurtenances. Accompanying the dwelling, being attached or detached, located in the rear of the dwelling, shall either be a carport or a residential parking garage. Dwelling, mobile home: A detached residential unit with the following characteristics: (1) Designed for long-term occupancy as opposed to transient locations, containing sleeping accommodations and toilet facilities with plumbing and electrical connections provided. (2) A structure built in a factory, transported to its site on a chassis which is a distinct part of the floor system, built to arrive at the site where it is to be occupied as a dwelling unit complete (with the exception of a double-wide mobile home which arrives at the site in two or more sections), including major appliances, and ready for occupancy except for necessary unpacking and assembly operations. (3) For all units built since June 15, 1976, documentation of compliance with the National Mobile Home Construction and Safety Standard Act (United States Department of Housing and Urban Development certification) shall be required. (4) For all units built prior to June 15, 1976, documentation of compliance with specifications prescribed by the American National Standards Institute shall be required. (5) Mobile homes do not meet Southern Standard Building Code requirements for house construction or prefabricated housing. (6) A mobile home shall not be construed to be a travel trailer, motor home, or other form of recreational vehicle. (7) Documentation of compliance with specifications prescribed by the American National Standards Institute are required for all mobile homes. (8) Removal of the wheels and axles and placement on a foundation does not change the structure's classification as a mobile home. Camping style trailers are not mobile homes. (9) An attached residential parking garage shall be required. Dwelling, multiple-family: A residential unit or portion thereof designed for three or more dwelling units, with the number of families in residence not exceeding the number of dwelling units provided. Dwelling, single-family: (1) A detached residential dwelling unit, other than a mobile home, hotel or motel designed for and occupied by one family, containing rooms for living, sleeping, toilet facilities, one kitchen and a residential parking garage. (2) A single-family dwelling is a structure or portion of a structure designed, arranged and used for occupancy by one or more persons living as a single housekeeping unit or family which meets or exceeds the following standards: a. Minimum width in excess of 20 feet. b. Minimum square footage as required by the zoning district in which it is located. c. The roof shall have a minimum of four/twelve (4:12) roof pitch and shall have a surface of wood stakes, asphalt composition, wood shingles, concrete, fiberglass or metal tiles, slate, built-up gravel materials, or other materials approved by the building official. d. The exterior siding material shall consist of wood, masonry, concrete, stucco, masonite, metal or vinyl lap or other material of like appearance, and shall comply with the minimum requirements of the applicable zoning district. e. The structure must be attached to a permanent foundation comprised of masonry blocks joined by mortar or poured concrete walls having a height of at least 18 inches and four inches wide. f. The structure must be constructed according to standards established either by the State Minimum Standard Codes, as amended from time to time, or the Standard Building Code if locally adopted, or the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act, or the State of Georgia Industrialized Building Act. g. Manufactured homes and industrialized buildings placed in residential zoning districts or areas shall meet the minimum compatibility standards set forth in section 67-38 in addition to the district standards applicable to all housing located therein. Dwelling, single-family attached: A residential unit subdivided by a coincidental property line and wall which separates the structure into a maximum of two dwelling units, each occupying its own lot. The two lots created by the coincidental property line and wall shall each contain at least: (1) Fifty percent of the minimum lot area in the zoning district in which they are located; and (2) Fifty percent of the minimum gross floor area in the zoning district in which they are located. An attached single-family structure must meet all front, rear and side yard setback requirements in the zoning district in which it is located, except for the coincidental property line and wall. Each dwelling unit must be separately metered for all utilities and the coincidental property line and wall must be fire-rated and extend from the foundation to the roof decking of the structure. Otherwise, an attached single-family structure must meet all standards that would be required for two-family dwellings in the zoning districts in which they are located. Each dwelling unit shall contain rooms for living, sleeping, toilet facilities, one kitchen, and a residential parking garage. Dwelling, townhouse: Attached dwellings connected by a common wall, sold in fee simple along with the individual lot upon which the dwelling is located. Accompanying the dwelling, being attached or detached, located in the rear of the dwelling, shall either be a carport or a residential parking garage. Dwelling, two-family: A detached residential unit containing two dwelling units, designed for occupancy by not more than two families living independent of each other. Each dwelling unit shall be accompanied by an attached residential parking garage. Dwelling unit: One room, or rooms connected together, constituting a separate, independent housekeeping establishment for owner occupancy, for rental or lease on a weekly, monthly, or longer basis and physically separated from any other rooms or dwelling units which may be in the same structure, and containing independent living, sleeping, toilet and single cooking facilities. Family: One or more persons occupying a premises and living as a single housekeeping unit, as distinguished from a group occupying a boarding house, lodging house, hotel, fraternity or sorority house. Farm: A farm includes all places of three or more acres devoted to the raising of agricultural products regardless of the quantity or value of production. Firing range: A public or privately owned facility designed and operated for the purpose of discharge of rifles, shotguns and handguns at targets within a controlled setting. Flood hazard area: The area possibly threatened by periodic flooding as determined by various data, e.g., maps provided by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, United States Soil Conservation Service, Army Corps of Engineers, Federal Emergency Management Agency, or hydrological studies utilizing generally accepted engineering practices. Flood hazard areas shall include all lands underneath a permanent body of water, e.g., a lake, pond, river, and stream, and all land within the limits of a flood hazard area having a 100-year return frequency. Floor area, gross: The total number of square feet of floor area in a building determined by horizontal measurements between the exterior faces of walls, excluding unfinished basement areas, attics, porches, carports and garages. Garage, public parking: A structure, lot or any portion thereof which is open to the public in which one or more vehicles are housed or kept, not including exhibition, show rooms, storage of cars or cars for sale. Garage, repair: A building or structure used to house, cover or protect automobiles or other vehicles from the elements while repairs are being made thereto. Garage, residential parking: Shall mean an enclosed structure attached to or part of the principal dwelling used for housing at least two vehicles and has the following minimum dimensions: vehicular entrance height, eight feet; interior height, ten feet; vehicular entrance width, 16 feet; and overall garage width and depth, 24 feet. The floor shall be constructed of concrete. Concrete floors shall be reinforced, where appropriate, and a minimum of four inches in thickness with appropriate fill and base. Where residential parking garages are constructed, such structures shall not be enclosed for living space, storage purposes or any other purpose without first obtaining an administrative variance from the city. In addition to all other requirements for an administrative variance under this chapter, applicants must also meet the following requirements: (1) Where applicable, applicants must obtain the prior written approval of their homeowner's association, certifying that the enclosure complies with all terms, conditions and restrictions contained in their neighborhood covenants (CCR's). A copy of this written approval must be submitted along with the application for administrative variance. Applications submitted without this approval will not be accepted. (2) All applications for an administrative variance to construct an enclosed garage must be presented to the city for prior review and approval. (3) The applicant must submit plans and pictures to the city illustrating the proposed enclosure. (4) If the application for administrative variance is approved by the city, the applicant must next obtain all appropriate permits from the city's building department. (5) The final enclosed garage must be inspected by the city's building inspector, and a certificate of occupancy must be issued. (6) Notwithstanding anything in this ordinance to the contrary, no administrative variance to construct an enclosed garage will be issued where the applicant will not have adequate parking remaining after the enclosure. The decision of what constitutes adequate parking shall be in the sole discretion of the city. Ground coverage: The area of a lot occupied by all buildings expressed as a percentage of the gross area of the lot. Home occupation: An occupation for gain or support customarily conducted on the premises by a person or family residing thereon. The term "home occupation" shall not be deemed to include a tourist home. Hospital: An institution receiving in-patients, or a public institution receiving out-patients, and authorized under Georgia law to render medical, surgical and/or obstetrical care. The term "hospital" shall include a sanitarium for the treatment and care of mental patients, alcoholics or drug addicts, but shall not include office facilities for the private practice of medicine or dentistry. Hotel: A building in which overnight accommodations without separate cooking facilities are provided to the public. The term "hotel" includes the terms "motel" and "tourist court". Industrialized building: Any structure or component thereof which is wholly or in substantial part made, fabricated, formed, or assembled in manufacturing facilities for installation on a building site and has been manufactured in such a manner that all parts or processes cannot be inspected at the installation site without disassembly, damage to, or destruction thereof. Industrialized buildings are constructed and regulated in accordance with the "Industrialized Buildings Act," Georgia Law 1981 pp 1637-1643 (O.C.G.A. tit. 8, ch. 2, art. 2, pt. 1). Inoperable vehicle: Any motorized vehicle incapable of immediately being driven. Junk/salvage yard: Any use on public streets or private property involving the parking, storage or disassembly of vehicles and/or machinery; the storage, sale or resale of used auto parts, tires, scrap iron, metal; used plumbing fixtures, old stoves, refrigerators and other old household appliances; used brick, wood, or other building/structural materials, used paper, rags or other scrap materials. These uses shall be considered junk yards whether or not all or part of these operations are conducted inside a building or in conjunction with, or accessory to other uses of the premises. Junked vehicle: Any wrecked, non-operable, dismantled automobile, truck or other vehicle which does not bear a current state license plate. Kennel: The following shall constitute a kennel: (1) Commercial kennel: Any location which provides board and care for dogs, cats, or other small animals for pecuniary gain. (2) Noncommercial kennel: a. In an RA zoning district outside a subdivision, on a tract of land having a minimum area of three acres, a noncommercial kennel is a location upon which more than six dogs are kept as pets, or otherwise not for pecuniary gain; b. In an R-1, R-2, R-3, RM, or RMH zoning district, or in an RA zoning district where the location does not meet the requirements of paragraph (2)a., a noncommercial kennel is a location upon which more than three dogs, cats, or other small animals, or any combination thereof, are kept as pets, or otherwise not for pecuniary gain. Kindergarten: A state-approved institution for the education of preschool aged children. Loading space, off-street: Space logically and conveniently located for bulk pickups and deliveries, scaled to the size of delivery vehicles expected to be used. Lot: A lot of record, or any combination of lots of record, held in a single ownership by one owner, or in common ownership by more than one owner which has both lot area requirements established by this chapter for the zoning district in which such tract of land is located and for the use proposed for the tract of land. Lot, corner: A lot situated at the intersection of two public streets, or bounded on two or more adjacent sides by public street lines. Lot frontage: That portion of a lot adjacent to a public street. Lot, interior: A lot other than a corner lot or a through lot. Lot line: A boundary of a lot. Lot line is synonymous with property line. Lot of record: An individual lot or a lot which is a part of a subdivision, the map of which has been recorded in the office of the Clerk of Superior Court of Henry County, Georgia, or a parcel of land the deed of which has been recorded in the office of the Clerk of Superior Court of Henry County. Lot, through: A lot other than a corner lot, having frontage on more than one public street, or a corner lot having frontage on three or more public streets. Lot width: The distance between the side lot lines, measured along the front yard setback line as established by this chapter, or if no setback line is established, the horizontal distance between the side lot lines measured along the public street lines. Manufactured home: A structure defined by and constructed in accordance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, as amended, 42 U.S.C. 5401 et seq. The definition in effect as of the date of the adoption of this part reads as follows: Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or when erected on-site, is 320 square feet or more and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this paragraph except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary and complies with the standards established under this chapter. (1) Mass-produced in a factory; (2) Designed and constructed for transportation to a site for installation and use when connected to required utilities; (3) Either an independent, individual building or a module for combination with other elements to form a building on the site. Mini-warehouse: A building or portion thereof used for dead storage, mainly of the excess personal property of an individual or family, but also of small amounts of goods or merchandise for businesses or individuals. Mini-warehouses shall not include retail sale on the premises, commercial repair or other services, manufacturing or any other commercial use. Mobile home community: A mobile home development with continuing local general management and with special facilities for common use by the occupants, including such items as common recreational buildings and areas, common open space, laundries and the like. Mobile home development: A mobile home development includes mobile home parks, mobile home subdivisions and mobile home condominiums. Mobile home park: A parcel of land that has been planned and improved for the placement of mobile homes for living or sleeping purposes, or where spaces or lots are set aside and offered for rent for use by mobile homes for living or sleeping purposes, including any land, building or structure or facility used by occupants of mobile homes on such premises. A mobile home park does not include an automobile or mobile home sales lot on which unoccupied mobile homes are parked for inspection or sale. Mobile home or manufactured home subdivision: A tract of land that is used, designated, maintained or held out for sale of lots to accommodate mobile homes or manufactured housing. A mobile home or manufactured home subdivision shall meet the requirements of the zoning district in which it is located. Motel: A building in which lodging or board and lodging are provided to transient guests or offered to the public for compensation, in which ingress or egress to and from all rooms are made primarily directly from an exterior walkway rather than from an inside lobby. A building in which overnight accommodations without separate cooking facilities are provided to the public. The term "motel" includes the term "hotel" and "tourist court". Move in house: Pre-existing dwelling, relocated to another lot. All such houses shall have an attached residential parking garage constructed prior to the certificate of occupancy being issued. All move in housing shall be accompanied by appropriate bonds. Nonconforming use: Use of lands and/or structures for a purpose or in a manner contrary to provisions of this chapter; generally of two types: (1) Lawful, where such use is rendered nonconforming by terms of this chapter; and (2) Unlawful, where such use was illegal when commenced or became so prior to adoption of this chapter. Nursery school or day care facility: A firm, partnership, corporation, individual, or other business entity providing care for more than six children not related by blood or marriage or not the legal wards or foster children of the attendant adult or adults. Official City of Hampton sign: Any sign designated as an official City of Hampton sign by minute action of the Hampton City Council. Parking space, off-street: An off-street parking space consisting of a space adequate for parking an automobile with room for opening doors on both sides, together with properly related access to a public street or alley and maneuvering room, design standards for which are contained in this chapter. Planning and zoning commission: The City of Hampton, Georgia Planning and Zoning Commission as appointed by the city council. Planning and zoning department: The professional planning staff of Hampton, Georgia, responsible for administering the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations and land use plan. The function of the planning and zoning department is to promote and enhance the health, safety and welfare of the residents, property owners, and businesses within the city, as well as promote the aesthetics, conservation and preservation of natural and historical elements of the city. Furthermore, the planning and zoning department shall uphold and enforce its mission through policies, goals, objectives, programs and services that encourage high quality development as well as maintenance and revitalization of existing neighborhoods. Planning and zoning director: The person, officer, or official and his authorized representative(s) designated by the city council as its agent for the administration of this chapter. The planning and zoning director shall be the head of the planning and zoning department. The planning and zoning director may sometimes be referred to as, and shall have the same meaning as, "planning and zoning administrator". Principal building: The building or structure containing or to contain the principal use of a lot. Principal permitted use: That use of a lot which is among the uses allowed as a matter of right under the zoning classifications. Private alleyway: Shall mean an alley located in the rear of apartments, townhouses or condominiums in RM-1, RM-2 or RM-3 districts, respectively, that provides residents with vehicular access. Private alleyways shall be maintained by the adjoining property owners, homeowners' associations, or condominium associations. Private alleyways shall be constructed to meet the following requirements: private alleyways shall be a minimum of 18 feet in width and 16 feet thereof shall be paved with concrete or asphalt. Concrete alleyways shall be reinforced and have a minimum depth of six inches with appropriate base. Asphalt alleyways shall consist of a minimum of two inches of type "E" or "F" asphalt topping, binder, and six inches of graded aggregate base. Private alleyways, at a minimum, shall be constructed so as to provide adequate turning radii onto public streets, driveways, residential parking garages and carports for full-size noncommercial two-axle vehicles. Curbs and gutters should be provided, but are not required. Private alleyways shall not have dead-ends. Private deed restrictions or covenants: Private deed restrictions or covenants imposed on land by private land owners. They bind and restrict the land in the hands of present owners and subsequent owners. They are enforceable only by the land owners involved and not by the city or other public agency. Public street: A public street includes the land between the right-of-way lines, whether improved or unimproved, and may comprise pavement, shoulders, curb and gutter, sidewalks, drainage ditches and structures and other areas within the public street lines. Where applicable, "public street" is synonymous with "court", "road", "run", "trail", "trace", and other such words which commonly refer to traffic thoroughfares. Public streets are classified as follows: (1) Expressway. The expressway system includes high volume limited access thoroughfares through the city. These include U.S. 19/41. (2) Major arterial road. Major arterial roads are defined as Old Georgia 3, Woolsey Road, Georgia Highway 20, Hampton and Locust Grove Road, Oak Street (portions of Oak Street are not up to arterial standards and the property owner and/or developer for any properties developed off of Oak Street will be required to deposit sufficient amount of money to bring that portion of Oak Street that fronts the property to be developed up to a major arterial standard is defined as a road of a minimum of 24 feet in width, curb, gutter, and storm drainage), and any other roads subsequently developed or brought to arterial standards as identified by the city council. (3) Minor arterial. An arterial public street similar in function to a major arterial but which is intended to provide moderate levels of traffic flow and greater access to abutting properties. Minor arterials serve as traffic feeders to major arterials and for regional travel. (4) Collector public street. A public street which carries traffic from local public streets to minor and major arterial public streets, and may include the principal entrance of a development. (5) Local public street. A public street designed to provide access to adjoining properties within a subdivision or other development. (6) Cul-de-sac. A local public street with only one outlet, closed and terminated by a vehicular turnaround. (7) Marginal access public street. A public street which is parallel to, and adjacent to an arterial public street or highway and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. Public water facilities: Mains and service lines owned and operated by the city water department or the Henry County Water and Sewerage Authority. Setback: The area designated by this chapter in which a structure may not be erected, as measured from the property boundaries of the lot or from the buffer line if a buffer is required. Shopping center: A group of commercial establishments having a building composition that is a single architectural unit and is not a miscellaneous assemblage of stores. It is planned and developed as a unit, related in location, size and type of shops to the trade area that the unit serves, and provides on-site parking in definite relationship to the types and sizes of stores. Shopping centers are classified by type, each distinctive in its own function: (1) Neighborhood shopping center. Provides for the sale of convenience goods (foods, drugs, sundries, etc.) and personal services (laundry, dry cleaning, barbering, shoe repair, etc.) for the day to day living needs of the immediate neighborhood. It is generally built around a supermarket which is the major tenant. Neighborhood shopping centers may have an average gross leasable area (GLA) close to 50,000 square feet and range between 30,000 square feet and 100,000 square feet GLA. Typically, the lot size for a neighborhood shopping center is between four and ten acres, with a trade area population of 5,000 to 40,000 thousand people. (2) Community shopping center. Provides for the sale of a wide range of durable goods and other types of merchandise in addition to convenience goods and personal services found in a neighborhood shopping center and typically has a junior department store or specialty store as the major tenant. Community shopping centers may have an average GLA close to 150,000 square feet and range between 100,000 square feet and 300,000 square feet GLA. Typically, the lot size for a community shopping center is between ten and 30 or more acres, with a trade area population of 40,000 to 150,000 people. (3) Regional shopping center. Provides for the sale of a wide range and variety of general merchandise, apparel, furniture, furnishings, novelties, personalized services and amusements in addition to those items found in neighborhood and community shopping centers. Typically, there are several major tenants which include nationally known department stores and grocery stores. Regional shopping centers may have an average GLA close to 400,000 square feet and range between 300,000 square feet and 1,000,000 square feet GLA. Typically, the lot size for a regional shopping center is 30 to 50 or more acres, with a trade area population in excess of 150,000 people. Sign: See definitions contained in article XII of this chapter. Stable, private: A stable with a capacity of not more than four horses, mules or other draught animals. Stable, public: A stable other than a private stable with a capacity of more than four horses, mules or other draught animals. Structure: Anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on the ground or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. Among other things, structures include, but are not limited to, site-built buildings, industrialized buildings, manufactured homes, mobile homes, gasoline pumps, walls, fences, billboards, signs and satellite dish antennas. Subdivision: The division of a parcel or tract of land into two or more lots for the purpose of creating sites for development, the rearrangement of existing lot lines, or for the purpose of transfer of ownership. Every subdivision must have frontage on a paved city or county road. Every lot must have a minimum of 30 feet of road frontage and comply with the zoning ordinance. A subdivision may include the construction, extension, or relocation of public improvements including public streets, public rights-of-way, public water and sewer facilities and other improvements for the purpose of creating building sites. All subdivisions must comply with the City of Hampton Subdivision Ordinance. Surface water: Includes any river, creek, stream, or body of water located within the Towaliga Watershed Protection District. Tourist home: A dwelling in which sleeping accommodations are provided or offered to transient visitors for compensation. Townhouse, fee simple: See Dwelling, "townhouse". Toxic: The word "toxic" as used herein shall mean any chemical or substance that has been defined as toxic by the Environmental Protection Agency of the United States (E.P.A.), Environmental Protection Department of the State of Georgia (E.P.D.), or the Department of Agriculture of the State of Georgia (A.D.). Trailer (motor home): A motorized vehicle, designed and/or maintained for use as a temporary dwelling or sleeping place for travel or recreation purposes exclusively, having no foundation other than wheels or jacks. Trailer (travel): A non-motorized vehicle, pulled by an automobile or truck designed and/or maintained for use as a temporary dwelling or sleeping place for travel or recreation purposes exclusively. Trailer park: A parcel of land which is used solely for the rental or lease of lots for transient campers, trailers, motor homes or temporary parking of any other recreational vehicle that is not a mobile home. Underground water: Any underground water located within the Towaliga Watershed Protection District. Use: The purpose or purposes for which land or a building is designed, arranged, intended, or for which said land or building is occupied, maintained or leased. Variance: A variance is a minimal variation of the terms of this chapter where such variance will not be contrary to the public interest and where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not the result of the actions of the applicant, a literal enforcement of the chapter would result in unnecessary and undue hardship. As used in this chapter, a variance is authorized only for height, area and size of a structure or size of yards and open spaces; establishment or expansion of a use otherwise prohibited shall not be allowed by variance, nor shall a variance be granted because of the presence of nonconformities in the zoning district or uses in adjoining zoning districts. Vehicle, abandoned: A vehicle which does not bear a current state license plate, unless said vehicle is stored within a completely enclosed building or it is stored on a bona fide sales lot and is in a satisfactory operating condition. Watershed protection district: An overlay district with regulations for the protection of drinking water resources for certain drainage basins in Henry County. Yard: A required open space located on the same lot as the principal building, unoccupied and unobstructed except for accessory uses and for shrubs and fences. Yard, front: That area of a lot lying between the abutting public street line and the principal building of the lot and extending across the front of a lot from side lot line to side lot line. Yard, rear: That area of a lot extending across the rear of a lot from side lot line to side lot line and lying between the rear lot line and the principal building on the lot. Yard, side: That area of a lot between the side lot line and the principal building on the lot extending from the front yard to the rear yard. Zoning district: Area of zoned property within the City of Hampton, Georgia, and shown on the official zoning map which is part of this chapter. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 4, 5, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 170-E, § 2, 6-16-05; Ord. No. 402 , § 1, 9-22-15) Sec. 67-23. - Temporary definitions. (a) For the purposes of this Zoning Ordinance, notwithstanding any definition contained herein, the following definitions shall temporarily apply for the period provided in subsection (b) below: (1) In every place that it shall appear, the term "planning commission" and/or "planning and zoning commission" shall mean the Henry County Municipal/County Planning and Zoning Commission as that term is defined in the Henry County Zoning Ordinance. This definition shall control even where the defined term appears as "Hampton Planning Commission" and/or "Hampton Planning and Zoning Commission." (2) In every place that it shall appear, the term "planning department" and/or "planning and zoning department" shall mean the Henry County Planning and Zoning Department as that term is defined in the Henry County Zoning Ordinance. This definition shall control even where the defined term appears as "Hampton Planning Department" and/or "Hampton Planning and Zoning Department." (3) In every place that it shall appear, the term "planning director" and/or "planning and zoning director" shall mean the Henry County Planning and Zoning Director as that term is defined in the Henry County Zoning Ordinance. This definition shall control even where the defined term appears as "Hampton Planning Director" and/or "Hampton Planning and Zoning Director." (b) The temporary definitions contained in subsection (a) above shall remain in effect until the 31st day after the official hire date of a Planning and Zoning Director for the City of Hampton Planning and Zoning Department. (c) (1) It is the express intention of the Hampton City Council by implementing these temporary definitions to have all City of Hampton Zoning matters be studied and reviewed by the Henry County Planning and Zoning Department and come before the Henry County Planning and Zoning Commission until such time as the city can implement its own planning and zoning department and hire a planning and zoning director therefor. (2) Once the city's planning and zoning department has been created and on the 31st day after the official hire date of a planning and zoning director, it is the express intention of the Hampton City Council for this Zoning Ordinance, without the need for further action, to be implemented by the Hampton Planning and Zoning Department and for all Hampton zoning matters to be studied and reviewed by the Hampton Planning and Zoning Department and to come before the Hampton Planning and Zoning Commission. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 4, 5, 9-10-02) Secs. 67-24—67-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICIAL ZONING MAP; ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS
Sec. 67-31. - Zoning map adopted; seal. (a) The City of Hampton, Georgia is hereby divided into zoning districts, as shown on the official zoning map which, together with all explanatory matter thereon, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter. (b) The official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor, attested by the city clerk, and bearing the seal of the city under the following words: "This is to certify that this is the Official Zoning Map referred to in the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Hampton, Georgia." Included on the map shall be the adoption date of the map by the City Council of Hampton. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-32. - Amendments to official zoning map. (a) If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes are made in land use, zoning district boundaries, and/or other matter portrayed on the official zoning map, such changes shall be entered on the official zoning map within seven days after the amendment has been approved by the city council. Such changes shall be recorded in the minutes of the city council meeting where the changes are adopted as follows: "This is to certify that by official action of the City Council, that this is the Official Zoning Map of the City of Hampton, Georgia, as adopted (date) and as referred to in the zoning ordinance of the City," which entry shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk. (b) No changes or alterations of any nature shall be made to the official zoning map except in conformity with the procedures set forth in this chapter. (c) Regardless of the existence of purported copies of the official zoning map, which may from time to time be made or published for uses outside the official and authoritative uses of the city council, mayor or planning and zoning department; the official zoning map as located within the planning and zoning department shall be the governing and final authority as to the current zoning status of the city. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-33. - Replacement of official zoning map. The city council, at any time or when deemed necessary or appropriate, may adopt a new zoning map, which shall supercede the prior official zoning map. Any or all maps declared through this chapter to be official zoning maps by the city council shall be identified by the signature of the mayor and attested by the city clerk and shall include the date of adoption as well as bear the seal of the city and shall contain the following words: "This is to certify that by official action of the City Council, that this is the Official Zoning Map of the City of Hampton, Georgia, as adopted (date) and as referred to in the zoning ordinance of the City." (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-34. - Rules for interpretation of district boundaries. Where uncertainty exists with respect to the location of the boundaries of any zoning district within the city limits, the following rules shall apply: (1) District boundaries shall be indicated as following property lines and shall not include railroad lines, centerlines of public streets, highways, public street lines or right-of-way/utility lines, unless such railroad lines, centerlines of public streets, highways, public street lines, or right-of-way/utility lines are part of or within an officially designated zoning district/boundary. (2) Where a district boundary line as appearing on the official zoning map at the time of enactment of this chapter divides a lot or is partially indicated on a lot or lots and where there is a discrepancy as to the actual zoning of said property(ies), said lot or lots shall be designated as having a zoning specific to the current use of the land. Should the property be vacant or contain a residential land use upon said parcel(s), the designated zoning of the land shall be that which is compatible to the site development requirements of the Code of Hampton, Georgia, that most closely reflect the current use of the land. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-35. - Zoning districts. RA (Residential-Agricultural): Low density residential subdivision, developments or divisions of land used for the purpose of single-family housing/farming uses, raising of crops, horticulture, raising of livestock, keeping and/or caring for non-domestic animals or those permitted uses as further designated in this district. R-1 (Single-Family Residential): Low density residential subdivisions, developments or divisions of land used for the sole-purpose of single-family housing and/or for those permitted uses as further designated in this district. R-2 (Single-Family Residential): Moderate density residential subdivisions, developments or divisions of land used solely for the purpose of single-family housing and/or for those permitted uses as further designated in this district. Such housing shall be developed on public water and public sewer. R-3 (Single-Family Residential): Moderate to high density residential subdivisions, developments or divisions of land used for the sole purpose of single-family housing and/or for those permitted uses as further designated in this district. Such housing shall be developed on public water and public sewer. RM (Residential Multifamily): High density residential subdivisions, developments or divisions of land used for the purpose of single-family attached and detached housing, multifamily housing, town homes, condominiums and/or for those permitted uses as further designated in this district. Such housing shall be developed on public water and public sewer. RMH (Residential Mobile Homes): Moderate to high density residential mobile home parks, subdivisions, developments or divisions of land used for the purpose of single-family attached and detached housing, multifamily housing, and/or for those permitted uses as further designated in this district. Such housing shall be developed on public water and public sewer. OI (Office-Institutional): Business and office parks/complexes or individual buildings established for the purpose of professional services to the general public or for private clientele that are not within a residential home or within a residentially designated zoning district. C-1 (Neighborhood Commercial): Commercial and/or retail establishments that serve the shopping needs of residential areas of a community and that are within walking distance or within a short traveling distance of a vehicle. Such traveling distances shall be within a one-mile radius of residential subdivisions or communities that are oriented toward a more pedestrian-friendly scale. C-2 (General Commercial): Commercial and/or retail establishments that serve the shopping needs of residential areas of a community as well as other nonresidential land uses. Such land uses may not be within a short walking distance but may be considered a short traveling distance in a vehicle. Such traveling distances shall be within a two- or three-mile radius of residential and nonresidential subdivisions of lands or communities. C-3 (Heavy Commercial): Commercial and/or retail establishments that serve the shopping needs of a region or multiple jurisdictions or divisions of the city or state. Such land uses are not within a walking distance but are considered a reasonable traveling distance in a vehicle. Such traveling distances shall be within city or adjoining city boundaries and shall be within a ten- to fifteen-mile radius of residential and nonresidential subdivisions of lands or communities. M-1 (Light Manufacturing): Manufacturing/warehousing lands uses that are nuisance-free (air pollution, chemicals, etc.) and that provide no health or safety hazard to the environment or persons. Such businesses are low to no generators or hazardous waste, materials or producers of high risk elements that can have a permanent impact on the environment or persons. Uses shall be limited to assembly and accessory production or warehousing or risk-free products. Uses shall allow for inside or outside storage. M-2 (Heavy Manufacturing): Manufacturing land uses that are medium to high risk of nuisance or obnoxious materials (air pollution, chemicals, etc.) and that provide a medium to high health or safety threat to the environment or persons. Such businesses are potential generators of hazardous waste, materials or producers of high risk elements that can have a permanent impact on the environment or persons. This district is designed to provide for heavy repairs or manufacturing of products not conducive to, or compatible with, existing residential communities. Uses may allow for inside or outside storage with a high risk to the environment or persons. PD (Planned Development): An overlay district to provide for innovative development and site design standards for the combined use of residential and nonresidential land uses. FP (Flood-Protection district): An overlay district reflecting provisions of the FEMA flood-prone area studies, incorporating by reference the boundaries of the FIRM flood maps depicting the limits of the 100-year flood. TOWPD (Towaliga Watershed Protection district): An overlay district with regulations for protection of the Towaliga River and tributaries in its drainage basin and protection of city water resources. MU (Mixed-Use): The purpose of this district is to provide locations for office, institutional, personal service and various types of residential uses, accessory uses or structures, and essential public services. Lots and parcels may be used for a single use, or may contain a mixture of uses within a single development site. Accessory uses and structures and essential public services are permissible. The preferred organization is retail on the ground level with office and residential above. MSHOD (Main Street Historic Overlay district): An area of specific historic character requiring additional review and standards to maintain the specific historic character inherent in the area. The MSHOD provides for a specific review process by staff and the historic preservation commission through which the historic preservation commission must issue a certificate of appropriateness (COA) for new development and any material change in appearance of existing buildings, structures and developments, as set forth herein. DPOD (Downtown Parking Overlay district): An area of specific character requiring modified standards to the city's parking regulations in order to maintain the specific character inherent in the area. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 170-F, 9-13-05; Ord. No. 416 , § 1, 4-12-16; Ord. No. 434 , § 1, 6-13-17) Sec. 67-36. - Manufactured homes; intent. (a) It is the intent of this Ordinance to encourage the provision of affordable housing in a general residential environment by permitting the use of manufactured homes meeting the definition of dwelling, single-family in all residential districts in which similar dwellings constructed on-site or otherwise are permitted, subject to the requirements and procedures set forth herein to assure similarity in the exterior appearance between such residentially-designed manufactured homes and dwellings which have been or may be constructed under these or other lawful regulations on lots in the same zoning district or general use. (b) Manufactured homes meeting the definition of dwelling, single-family, either individually or by specific model, shall be permitted in all residential districts subject to the requirements and limitations set forth in this Ordinance which are applicable to manufactured homes and the requirements and limitations applying generally to residential use in such zoning districts, including minimum lots, yard and building spacing, percentage of lot coverage, off-street parking requirements and approved foundations as required by law. (c) Manufactured homes placed on individual lots within the city limits shall be taxed in the same manner as comparable site-built homes within the area where the manufactured home is located. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-37. - Permitted locations. Manufactured homes which meet the definition of dwelling, single-family and the compatibility standards shall be permitted in all residential zoning districts. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-38. - Compatibility standards. Compatibility standards for manufactured homes meeting the definition of dwelling, single-family are as follows: (1) Manufactured homes qualifying as single-family dwelling shall be compared to site-built and other housing in the general area and within the same zoning district. Approval shall be granted by the city compatibility standards review committee upon the finding that the manufactured home is substantially similar or superior in size, siding material, roof material, foundation and general aesthetic appearance to: a. Site-built or other forms of housing which may be permitted under this Ordinance in the same zoning district or general area, or b. Existing development in the same zoning district or general area, or c. Proposed development permitted in the same zoning district or general area. (2) All towing devices, wheels, axles and hitches must be removed. (3) At each exit door there must be a landing that is a minimum of 36 inches by 36 inches. (4) If a residential parking garage is not part of the manufactured structure, then an attached residential parking garage must be constructed prior to a certificate of occupancy being issued. All documentation submitted to the compatibility standards review committee must show the method by which the residential parking garage will be added to the manufactured home. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-39. - Procedure for approval of manufactured homes classified as dwellings, single-family. The procedures for approval are as follows: (1) Applications for approval of placement of manufactured homes shall be made on a form or forms developed for that purpose and the completed application shall be submitted to the compatibility standards review committee for review and approval in accordance with this Code by filing the completed form or forms with the planning and zoning department. (2) Such applications shall include only information reasonably necessary to make determination as to conformity with the provisions of this Ordinance as applicable to each such structure and, as applicable, conformity with the standards herein, including photographs or renderings of the front and side of the manufactured home or mobile home exterior finish and other information reasonably necessary to make determinations required by this Code. (3) Approval or denial of the application shall be made within 30 days of the date of receipt of the application and all required supporting materials. The applicant shall be notified in writing of the approval, conditional approval or denial of the application within two working days after such decision is made. Conditional approval shall require that the specific conditions and the reasons therefore be stated in writing and be agreed to by the applicant; such conditions shall be binding upon the applicant upon agreement. In the case of disapproval, the reasons therefore shall be specifically stated in writing by designating each specific provision of this Code and ordinance which is not met and an explanation as to the reason or reasons why each such provision is not met. The applicant may appeal the decision of the city compatibility standards review committee to the city council who will hear said appeal within 30 days after the same is filed. The applicant may submit such additional information, documents or other materials as are deemed appropriate to the city council for its consideration in connection with any such appeal. The decision of the city council shall be in writing and shall specifically set forth findings of fact and identity specific provisions contained in this Ordinance upon which it relies, if the applicant's appeal is denied. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-40. - Compatibility standards review committee. For the purpose of reviewing the location of manufactured homes, other manufactured homes or mobile homes, as contemplated in this chapter, a compatibility standards review committee consisting of the planning and zoning director, the city public works director and the city manager is hereby established. A quorum shall consist of any of the three members, and the decision of any two of the three members shall be binding on the committee and the city. The committee shall adhere to the provisions of this Ordinance. In the event that one or more members of the committee is/are unable to participate in the review process contemplated in this section and the ordinance, then such named member or members may designate his or her associate or assistant as an alternate to act in the place of the named member until such member is able to again participate in the committee review process. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 6, 7, 9-10-02) ARTICLE IV. - GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 67-41. - Applicability to land, buildings and open space. No building, structure, land or open space shall hereafter be used or occupied and no building or structure or part thereof shall hereafter be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered unless in conformity with all of the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-42. - Every use must be upon a lot. No building or structure may be erected or use established unless upon a lot as defined by this chapter, except as otherwise provided herein. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-43. - One principal building on a lot. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, only one principal residential building and its accessory buildings may hereafter be erected on any one lot in any single-family or two-family residential district. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-44. - Annexation or unincorporated area additions. Henry County and the City of Hampton have substantially the same zoning ordinance. A tract of property that is annexed into the city will carry with it the same zoning classification it had under the Henry County Zoning Map and Ordinance, but shall be subject to the requirements and restrictions of the city's zoning ordinance as applied to the property's zoning. If for any reason, a property is annexed into the city which, prior to annexation, had no zoning classification, said property shall be zoned "RA" upon annexation. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-45. - Height and density. No building or other structure shall hereafter be erected or altered: (1) To exceed the height or bulk limits of this chapter; (2) To accommodate or house a greater number of families; (3) To occupy a greater percentage of lot area; (4) To have narrower or smaller rear yards, front yards, side yards, or other open spaces than herein required; or in any other manner be contrary to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-46. - Open space not to be encroached upon. No open space shall be encroached upon or reduced in any manner except in conformity to the yard, setback, off-street parking spaces, and such other regulations required by this chapter for the zoning district in which such building is located. Shrubbery, driveways, retaining walls, fences, curbs and planted buffer strips shall not be construed to be encroachments of yards. Open space areas as required by this chapter shall be permanently maintained as open space and appropriately landscaped with trees, shrubs, flowers, grass, stones, or other landscaping materials. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-47. - Required open space may not be used by another building. No part of any yard, other open space, or off-street parking or loading space required in connection with any building, structure, or use by this chapter shall be considered to be part of a required yard, or other open space, or off-street parking or loading space, for any other building, structure, or use except as otherwise provided herein. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-48. - Reduction of yards or lot area. Except as otherwise provided herein, no lot existing at the time of passage of this chapter shall be reduced, divided, or changed so as to produce a tract of land which does not comply with the minimum dimension or area requirements of this chapter for the district in which it is located unless said reduction or division is necessary to provide land which is needed and accepted for public use. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-49. - Lots with multiple frontage. In case of a corner lot, side yard setback requirements from the right-of-way of abutting public streets shall be equal to 75 percent of that lot where the main entrance into a residence is facing a side yard. It shall be permissible for purposes of this chapter, to construe the residence to be fronting on the public street other than that public street which said entrance faces, and side and rear yard requirements may be provided accordingly. If a building is constructed on a through lot having frontage of two roads not at an intersection, a setback from each road shall be provided equal to the front yard requirement for the district in which the lot is located. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-50. - Minimum lot size for residences using septic tank systems. All residential buildings utilizing a septic tank shall be on a lot of not less than 30,000 square feet with a minimum lot width of 125 feet and must be served by a public water system, regardless of any zoning classification which permits smaller lot sizes. With respect to existing platted lots, the Henry County Board of Health will evaluate each individual request for a permit on a case-by-case basis. This restriction on lot size does not apply to residential development served by public sewerage systems. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-51. - Landlocked lots. In the event property is a landlocked lot, as of the effective date of this chapter, the property owner shall be entitled to one building permit, provided: (1) No other principal building exists or is being constructed on said property; (2) No other valid building permit has been issued prior to the effective date of this chapter and is currently valid; (3) The property was and continues to be under single ownership since the effective date of this chapter; (4) The property owner has acquired a 30-foot easement to a city or city maintained public street, and said easement has been duly recorded and made a part of the property deed; and (5) In the event said property is divided, no additional permits will be issued. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-52. - Yards and other spaces. No part of a yard or other open space or off-street parking or loading spaces required for any one building shall be included as a part of the yard or off-street parking or loading spaces required for another building, except as specifically provided for herein. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-53. - Road frontage. In all zoning districts other than RA, Residential-Agricultural, each lot or parcel of land on which a principal building is to be erected shall have at least 30 feet of frontage on a city, county or department of transportation maintained public street. In the RA, Residential-Agricultural zoning district, the following road frontage requirements shall apply: (1) Lots consisting of two or more acres shall have at least 60 feet of frontage on a public road; (2) Lots consisting of less than two acres shall have at least 30 feet of frontage on a public road. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-54. - Substandard lots of record. Any lot of record existing at the time of the adoption of this chapter, which has an area or a width which is less than required by this chapter, shall be subject to the following exceptions and modifications: (1) Adjoining lots: When two or more adjoining and vacant lots within a non-approved development with continuous frontage are in a single ownership at the time of application and such lots have a frontage or lot area less than is required by the district in which they are located, such lots shall be re-platted or re-parcelled so as to create one or more lots which conform to the minimum frontage and area requirements of said district. (2) Lot not meeting minimum lot size requirements: When a lot has an area or frontage which does not conform with the requirements of the district in which it is located, but was a lot of record at the effective date of this chapter, such lot may be used for any use allowed in the zoning district in which it is located provided that all other requirements of this chapter are met. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-55. - Side and rear yards not required next to railroad. Within any nonresidential district, side yards and rear yards shall not be required adjacent to railroad rights-of-way. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-56. - Buildings under construction. Nothing in this chapter shall require any change in the construction or intended use of a building which is legally under construction or for which a building permit has been issued as of the effective date of this chapter and the construction of which shall be diligently pursued until completion. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-57. - Development projects under construction. Nothing in this chapter shall require any change in development or proposed use of properties which are legally under development or for which a development plan or preliminary plat has been approved as of the effective date of this chapter and the development of which shall be commenced within one year from said date. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-58. - Subdivision approval. No approval will be granted for a subdivision, or subsequent phase or addition to an existing subdivision, unless the property is served by a paved public street, with right-of-way sufficient to meet the requirements of the City of Hampton Subdivision Ordinance. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-59. - Operation of sanitary landfills. No private landfills shall be located within the city. All landfills that are located within the city shall be either owned, operated, or managed by the city and such landfills shall comply with all applicable federal and state laws, rules and regulations. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-60. - Encroachment on public rights-of-way. No building, structure, fence, service area, parking facility/area, loading area, except driveways shall be permitted to encroach on public right-of-way. All permanent structures or inorganic objects which are placed near but not within the public right-of-way shall be located as not to obstruct, hinder or impede the view or movement of pedestrian and vehicular traffic, and/or as not to become a nuisance, danger or hazard to the general public. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-61. - Accessory uses and structures. Accessory structures and uses shall be on the same lot and subordinate to the principal use or structure as follows: (1) Shall be permitted only in side or rear yard, unless otherwise stated. (2) Shall be set back not less than three feet from any property line, when located in a rear yard. Accessory structures in subdivisions with recorded easements for drainage, sanitary sewer and utilities shall not be permitted within the easement. (3) Shall not be erected on a lot prior to the time of construction of the principal structure to which it is accessory. (4) Accessory structures in residential districts shall not be used for any type of commercial operation, except in conjunction with a home occupation when approved by conditional use permit as authorized in this Code of Ordinances. (5) Accessory structures shall not be used as a residence or dwelling unit, except as otherwise provided in this Code of Ordinances. (6) Accessory structures in a subdivision shall not exceed 15 feet in height. (7) Accessory structures shall be located at least 12 feet from the principal structure on a lot. (8) Total square footage of accessory structures on a typical subdivision lot, except AG subdivisions as defined in the Hampton Subdivision Ordinance, shall not exceed 50 percent of the minimum required floor area (heated spaced) requirements of the zoning district.
(9) Accessory structures located in RA zoning in excess of one acre (not in a subdivision) will not be restricted to size, as long as the structure meets building codes and other requirements of this chapter. (10) Satellite dish antennas shall be permitted as accessory structures only in rear yards unless it can be documented that reception is impaired by such a location. In this case an antenna would be permitted in a side or front yard. If located within a front yard it cannot be within the required setback. Satellite dish antennas over 36 inches in diameter shall not be located on the roof of a single-family structure. (11) Swimming pools shall be considered accessory uses and shall comply with minimum side and rear yard requirements of the applicable zoning district. Setback minimum shall be measured from the decking or closed part of the pool structure to the property line. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-62. - Fire lanes. No-parking areas shall be established for the use of fire equipment and emergency vehicles to ensure access to the premises in cases of emergency. Said areas shall be marked: "Fire Lane-No Parking." The fire lane areas shall comply with provisions of the Henry County Code of Public Safety. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 8, 9, 9-10-02) Secs. 67-63—67-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - EXCEPTIONS, MODIFICATIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS
Sec. 67-71. - Yard space, general rule. Any building, structure, or use hereafter erected, altered or established shall comply with the yard space requirements of the district in which it is located except as specified herein. The required space for any building, structure, or use shall be contained on the same lot as the building, structure or use and such required yard space shall fall entirely upon land in a district or districts in which the principal use is permitted. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-72. - Exceptions to side yard requirements. When a lot of record has a width less than the frontage required in the district in which it is located and said lot cannot be increased in width as provided herein, then the planning and zoning director shall be authorized to reduce the side yard requirements for such lot; provided, however, that the side yard shall not be reduced to less than eight feet. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-73. - Exceptions to front yard requirements. (a) The front yard requirements of this chapter shall not apply on any lot where the average depth of the front yards of existing building on adjoining lots located wholly or in part within 200 feet on each side of such lot within the same block and zoning district and fronting on the same side of the public street is either greater or less than the minimum required front yard depth. (b) If the average depth of the front yard is less than the required minimum front yard depth, the depth of the front yard of such lot may be less than the required front yard depth but shall not be less than the average of the front yards of the aforementioned buildings. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-74. - Permitted encroachments upon yard setbacks. Architectural features such as cornices, eaves, steps, gutters and fire escapes may project up to three feet beyond a required setback line, except where such projections would obstruct driveways which are used or may be used for access of service and/or emergency vehicles; provided, however, in the case of automobile service stations, motels and similar uses which serve the motoring public, canopies shall be allowed over a driveway or walkway within the front yard not to extend from the principal building to a point any closer than 15 feet from the public street right-of-way line or future right-of-way line as designated by the land use plan. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-75. - Height exception, general rule. Any structure hereafter erected or altered shall comply with the height limitations of the district in which it is located except as specified herein. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-76. - Structures excluded from height limitations. The height limitations of this chapter shall not apply to church spires, belfries, flagpoles, monuments, cupolas, domes, ornamental towers, nor to observation towers not intended for human occupancy, water towers, transmission towers, radio or television towers or aerials. These exclusions shall not apply in the vicinity of airports. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-77. - Walls and fences. The setback requirements of this chapter as indicated in specific zoning districts, shall not prohibit or restrict any necessary retaining wall below ground foundation, fence or structure which shall be necessary for the proper development of a site as required by the city. Said wall, fence or structure shall be constructed and placed so as not to obstruct, hinder or impede the view and movement of pedestrian and vehicular traffic so as to become a nuisance, danger or hazard to the general public. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-78. - Visibility at intersections. On corner lots within all zoning districts, no fence, shrubbery or other obstruction to the view of traffic shall exceed a height of 2½ feet within a triangular area formed by the intersection of the right-of-way line, and a diagonal line which intersects the right-of-way lines at two points, each 20-foot distant from the intersection of the right-of-way lines, or, in the case of a rounded corner, from the point of intersection of their tangents; provided, however, signs, lights, or similar objects which are totally located at least 12 feet above the finished grade shall be permitted. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-79. - Yard fencing or walls. (a) No fence or wall in excess of six feet in height shall be erected in the front yard of any residential lot. No fence or wall in excess of eight feet in height shall be erected in the side or rear yards of any residential lot. Front, side and rear yards shall be defined as specified in this chapter. (1) Within the front yard areas of lots in residential subdivisions, fences or walls shall be limited to decorative fencing. Chain link, barbed wire, welded wire, hog wire, opaque, electrical and similar non-decorative fencing shall be prohibited in the front yards of lots within residential subdivisions. (2) Chain link and privacy fencing shall be permitted on residential subdivisions lots in the side and/or rear yards only. All other types of prohibited fencing previously mentioned in subsection (a)(1) shall be prohibited in the side and rear yards of lots within residential subdivisions but not necessarily in the side or rear yards of residential lots not within a subdivision. (3) Electrical fencing on residential lots as permitted on lots not within a subdivision and only in the side and rear yards shall be required to have signs indicating a warning of the type of fence and the voltage of the fence. Warning signs shall be placed at each corner of a fence and shall be no greater than four square feet in size. (4) Fences or walls located on lots not within a subdivision, which may have barb wire fencing shall limit the barb wiring to the top of or highest section of the proposed fence or wall. (5) Hog wire, welded wire or other similar types of fencing, which may be a danger or aesthetic nuisance shall be permitted only in the RA (Residential-Agricultural) district, except in RA district subdivisions. (b) No fence or wall in excess of eight feet in height shall be erected in the front, side or rear yards of any commercial, industrial or office institutional lot. (1) Fences or walls located on commercial, industrial or office institutional lots, which may have barb wire fencing (or similar type fencing) shall limit the barb wiring to the top of or highest section of the proposed fence or wall, as measured from ground level or the base of the fence. (2) Electrical fencing shall be required to have signs indicating a warning of the type of fence and the voltage of the fence. Signage shall be placed 15 feet apart around the fence and shall be no greater than four square feet in size. (3) Hog wire, welded wire or other types of fencing which may be a danger or aesthetic nuisance shall be permitted only adjacent to other nonresidential uses, not adjacent to existing residential subdivisions or properties. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-80. - Fences and hedges, measurement rule. Heights of fences shall be measured from ground level at the base of such fences to the top thereof. The placement or use of fences, hedges or foliage for the purpose of screening and/or privacy shall be upon or within the specified property lines of the property owner erecting or planting such fences, hedges or foliage. (Ord. No. 170, §§ 10, 11, 9-10-02) Sec. 67-81. - Fences and hedges, exception.
