ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 86-1. - Access of city agents to premises. Duly authorized agents of the city shall have access at all hours to the real property (excluding the interior of the dwelling house) of the consumer for the purpose of installing or removing city property, inspecting piping, inspecting wiring, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with any and all utility services provided by the city and its facilities. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.01, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 185, § 1, 9-14-04) Sec. 86-2. - Water, sewer extensions, easement required. Extensions to the water and sewer system shall be made only when the consumer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed to the city a permanent easement or right-of-way across any property traversed by the water and sewer lines. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.02, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-3. - Minimum charges. The minimum charge provided in the rate schedule shall be made for such connection subscribed for. Water furnished for a given lot shall be used on that lot only and, except for fire protection, the city shall not under any condition furnish water free of charge to anyone. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.03, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-4. - Rate schedule, special contracts. (a) The schedule of water and sewer rates shall be as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council and on file in the office of the city clerk. (b) Extraordinary circumstances related to industrial users, fire protection services, mobile home parks, and apartment complexes may be set by a separate rate schedule established by the mayor and council, or by special contract agreements made by the mayor and council after receiving recommendation from the city's engineer and attorney. Said schedule or contract shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for public inspection. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.04, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 288, § 1, 1-18-08) Sec. 86-5. - Billing, collection of charges. (a) The billing cycle for electrical, water and sewage services shall begin on the first day of each month and end on the last day of the month. Bills will be mailed out by the 15th day of each month. Bills shall be paid at the city hall. The failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent, nor relieve any person responsible therefor from payment of same. (b) The failure of electrical, water and sewage service customers to pay charges when due shall result in the automatic imposition of a penalty to be set from time to time by the city council. (c) All bills shall be due on or before the tenth day following the issuance thereof. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.05, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 94, Art. I, 12-10-96; Ord. No. 166, § 1, 8-13-02; Ord. No. 312, § 1, 10-8-08) Sec. 86-6. - Remedies for nonpayment of service. Upon nonpayment for electrical, water and sewage services by any customer, the city may exercise one or more of the following nonexclusive remedies: (1) The mayor shall be empowered to terminate electrical services for failure of customers and property owners of the city to pay their bills. The mayor, prior to the termination of service for nonpayment of bills, shall direct the city clerk to issue the following notice to the customer and/or property owner: Dear Customer: Your bill for electrical/water and sewage service for the month(s) of ____________ has not been paid. Your present amount due the City is $ ____________ for electrical service; $ ____________ for water service; and $ ____________ for sewage service. Delinquent payment penalties have been assessed in the amount of $ ____________ . If your bill is in error, or if you have a legitimate complaint to file with the City concerning your bill, you must appear before the City Clerk on ____________ at ____________ o'clock ____________ .M. to discuss any discrepancies that might exist. Failure to appear before the Clerk will result in the termination of electrical/water/sewage service to you on ____________ . If the customer and/or property owner fails to pay the bill and penalties prior to the hearing, and/or the customer and/or property owner fails to appear for the hearing set forth in the notice, the mayor shall be authorized to terminate electrical service on the date specified in the notice. (2) The city, at the discretion of the mayor, may issue, record and enforce a writ of fieri facias (fi. fa.) upon the property upon which the services were provided. (3) The city, at the discretion of the mayor, may institute civil proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction against the customer, owner or other responsible person. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.06, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 94, Art. II, 12-10-96) Sec. 86-7. - Suspension of service. (a) When water, sewer, electrical or other utility service is discontinued and all bills paid, the security deposit shall be refunded to the consumer by the city. Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, the security deposit will be applied by the city toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the customer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance as provided in section 86-9. (b) Service disconnected for nonpayment of bills will be restored only if the bills are paid in full and a security deposit has been paid together with a reconnection of service charge for each meter reconnected. The security deposit and reconnection charge shall be fixed from time to time by the mayor and council. (c) The city reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: (1) To prevent fraud or abuse. (2) Consumer's wilful disregard of the city's rules. (3) Emergency repairs. (4) Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control. (5) Legal processes. (6) Direction of public authorities. (7) Strike, riot, fire, flood, unavoidable accident. (8) Noncompliance with outdoor water restrictions imposed by the city, county, state or other governmental entity. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.07, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 185, § 2, 9-14-04; Ord. No. 277, § 1, 7-20-07) Sec. 86-8. - Complaints and adjustments, meter testing. (a) If the consumer believes his bill to be in error, he shall present his claim, in person, at the city hall before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill becomes delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The consumer may pay such bill under protest and such payment shall not prejudice his claim. (b) Settlement of claims and adjustments of bills are subject to the following additional provisions: (1) The city will make a special utility meter reading at the request of the consumer for a fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor, and council; provided, however, that if such special reading discloses that the meter was overread, no charge will be made. (2) Utility meters will be tested at the request of the consumer upon payment to the city of the actual costs of making the test; provided, however, that if the meter is found to over-register beyond three percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. (3) If the seal of a meter is broken by other than the city's representative, or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of his previous bills and/or from other proper data. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.08, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 185, § 3, 9-14-04) Sec. 86-9. - Liability of property owner. (a) Each owner of property shall be liable and responsible for the full payment of water, sewer, electrical or other utility services furnished to their property. The charges to be made for services rendered shall be made against the owners, occupants, tenants or lessees of the buildings or premises receiving the services from the city. (b) In addition to the right of termination of water, sewer, electrical or other utility services as provided herein, if enforcement of payment is necessary, the costs of such enforcement, including attorney's fees, shall be the expense of the firm, corporation, owner or lessee liable for the payment of water, sewer, electrical or other utility services, and collection may be made by process or procedures of law now available or which may hereafter be available, expressly including the right to cause a fi. fa. to be issued, levied and collected against the person who incurred the charges (excluding the property owner where required by O.C.G.A. § 30-60-17). (Ord. No. 77, § 1.09, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 77B, § 1, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 185, § 4, 9-14-04) Sec. 86-10. - Discontinuance or change of service, notice to city by consumer. Not less than three days' notice must be given in person or in writing at the city hall to discontinue water, sewer, electrical or other utility services. Not less than three days' notice must be given in person or in writing at the city hall of the change of ownership, lessee or occupant of any property in the city. The owner of the property shall be responsible for the collecting and paying of any past due water, sewer, electrical or other utility service bills incurred by the party from which the property was purchased. Failure to pay any past due water, sewer, electrical or other utility service bills shall result in the new owner being liable for paying such bills. The owner of the property shall be responsible for the collection and payment of any water, sewer, electrical or other utility service bills due the city from their lessee or occupant of their property. Failure to collect and pay any water, sewer, electrical or other utility service bills shall result in the owner of the property being liable for the payment of such bills. (Ord. No. 77, § 1.10, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 185, § 5, 9-14-04) Sec. 86-11. - Penalties for violation. Any consumer who, without the authorization of the city: (1) Connects onto a water, sewer, electrical or other utility line of the city; (2) Disconnects a water, sewer, electrical or other utility line from a water, sewer, electrical or other utility line of the city; (3) Connects onto a water, sewer, electrical or other utility meter of the city; (4) Disconnects a water, sewer, electrical or other utility meter of the city; (5) Moves, removes, changes or alters the location of a water, sewer, electrical or other utility meter; (6) Changes, alters or damages any water, sewer, electrical or other utility meter or water, sewer, electrical or other utility line so as to prevent proper registration of water, sewer, electrical or other utility passing through such water, sewer, electrical or other utility meter or line; (7) Obtains water, sewer, electrical or other utility services; (8) Prevents any other person from obtaining water, sewer, electrical or other utility services; (9) Obstructs or otherwise interferes with the reading or maintenance of any water, sewer, electrical or other utility meter; (10) Obstructs or otherwise interferes with any water, sewer, electrical or other utility line, fire hydrant, pumping station or any appurtenances to water, sewer, electrical or other utility facilities of the city; (11) Creates a hazardous or unsafe condition to the water, sewer, electrical or other utility facilities of the city; (12) Deposits any unauthorized material into the sewer system; (13) Operates a sewer system or septic tank system within the city without proper authorization from the mayor and council; (14) Discharges any unauthorized materials or chemicals into the sewer system; (15) Violates any provision of this chapter; Shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. Each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. No. 77, § 6, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 185, § 6, 9-14-04) Sec. 86-12. - Fixing of utility rates by resolution. All utility rates authorized by this chapter shall be as fixed from time to time by resolution of the mayor and city council where said resolution has been properly noticed and adopted in accordance with this Code and the City Charter. A current copy of the rate schedule shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for public inspection. (Ord. No. 294, § 1, 2-19-08) Secs. 86-13—86-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE[2]

Sec. 86-41. - Digging, drilling or boring well for water, consent required. No property owner, occupant, tenant or lessee will be allowed to dig, bore or drill within the city limits for the purpose of obtaining water for residential, commercial or industrial purposes without first filing an application with the city, paying an inspection fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council, and obtaining a written consent from the mayor and council. Any person installing a private well shall execute an agreement with the city stating that should facilities become available to the subject property that such person shall agree to connect onto the city water facilities and pay the required tap-on fees and deposits at the time those facilities are made available to such property owner. If water service is available to the property, wells will not be allowed, except for irrigation purposes. However, the well must be approved by the city before installation thereof. (Ord. No. 77, § 2.01, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-42. - Application for water service, security deposit. (a) The consumer shall make application for water and sewer service in person at the city hall and at the same time shall make a cash security deposit as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for water and sewer service. The city shall be authorized to use such deposits for payment of any delinquent balance, service charges, fines and penalties owed by the consumer to the city for water and sewer service. (b) Security deposits for residential consumers shall be refundable upon termination of service, provided that the deposit shall first be used for payment of any services, service charges, fines or penalties owed by the consumer to the city for water and sewer service. (c) Security deposits for nonresidential consumers shall be refundable when the consumer shall have maintained its account for water and sewer service with the city for 24 months without any delinquency or upon termination of service, provided that the deposit is not required for payment of any services, service charges, fines and penalties owed by the consumer to the city for water and sewer service. Consumers who have maintained nonresidential water and sewer accounts with the city without delinquency for 12 months as of December 21, 1994, shall be entitled to immediately apply for refund of their security deposits. (Ord. No. 77, § 2.02, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 77A, § 1, 12-21-94) Sec. 86-43. - Connection fee. Each consumer subscribing for the use of the water service of the city shall pay a nonrefundable connection fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 77, § 2.03, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-44. - Connection expenses. (a) All costs and expenses instant to the connection of the water service from the owner's building to the city's meter shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the connection of the building to the water system. (b) The connection to the city's water line, together with the installation of the meter, shall be made by the city. (c) The owner shall bear all costs and expenses (labor, materials, etc.) for the construction of the water line from the owner's property line to the nearest existing water line of the city that has sufficient capacity to serve the owner unless otherwise approved by the mayor and council. (d) The city reserves the right to install its meter at or near the property line or, at the city's option, on the customer's property within three feet of the property line. (e) The city reserves the right to refuse service unless the customer's lines and pipings are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections or backflow. (Ord. No. 77, § 2.04, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-45. - Consumer's responsibilities and liabilities. (a) Water furnished by the city shall be used for consumption by the consumer, members of their household and employees only. The consumer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use such water. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, nor other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard of this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal and/or discontinuance of service. (b) The consumer has the following additional responsibilities and duties: (1) Where the meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a consumer, a suitable place shall be provided by the consumer therefor, which is unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. (2) The consumer shall furnish and maintain a private cutoff valve on the consumer's side of the meter. (3) The consumer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer at the consumer's expense with the sanitary regulations of the state department of human resources. (4) In order to be received as a consumer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system; and all applicants, by becoming consumers of the city, covenant and agree that, so long as they continue to be consumers of the city, they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the city's water system. (Ord. No. 77, § 2.05, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-46. - Unauthorized turning on of city water. (a) The city shall tag each water meter for the purpose of controlling the use of city water. It is unlawful for any person other than the authorized city water personnel to turn on, turn off, or otherwise tamper with meters or connection facilities of the water system of the city. (b) Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. No. 77, §§ 2.06, 2.07, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-47. - Damage to waterworks. No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover or tamper with any meters, connections or equipment which are a part of the city water system. (Ord. No. 77, § 2.08, 10-12-93) Secs. 86-48—86-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SEWAGE DISPOSAL[3]

Sec. 86-76. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. City means the City of Hampton, its mayor and councilmembers, and any authorized agent. It shall also mean the area inside the city limits and any area outside the city limits where the city has jurisdiction over the sewer lines. Combined sewer means a sewer intended to serve as a sanitary sewer and a storm sewer, or as an industrial sewer and a storm sewer. Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and disposing of food and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from the industrial processes, as distinct sanitary sewage. Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration in milligrams per liter. Private sewage disposal system means a privately owned sewer system permitted by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. This term does not include septic systems not permitted by said department. Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and which is controlled by public authority. Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business building, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface waters and stormwaters as may be present. Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures or lagoons used for treatment of sewage presently owned or afterward acquired by the city. Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. Sewerage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. Slug means either or all of the following: (1) Any discharge of wastewater from whatever source which is more than three times the quantity of the average eight-hour flow discharges during the normal operational mode of said source and lasting longer than ten minutes; (2) Any discharge of wastewater from whatever source which contains over two times the average eight-hour concentration of any toxic substance whatsoever found in normal flows during normal operation mode; or (3) Any discharge of wastewater from whatever source which contains more than two times the average eight-hour concentration of BOD or suspended solids. Storm sewer or storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwater and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes. Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.01, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 243, § 1, 7-11-06) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 86-77. - Violations and penalties. (a) Any person found to be violating any provision of this article, except section 86-78, shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. (b) Any person who shall violate the provisions of section 86-78, or who shall continue any violation hereof beyond the time limit provided for in section 86-82, or who shall continue any other violation hereof beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) of this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day in which such a violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense and violation. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.02, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-78. - Damage to sewerage works prohibited. No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is part of the municipal sewerage works. Any person violating this provision shall be responsible for the full costs of repairing or correcting any damage caused to the sewer system of the city. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.03, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-79. - Inspectors, power and authority. Duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this article. All city employees will observe all company safety rules while on private properties. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.04, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-80. - Waste disposal, unlawful methods designated. (a) It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner, upon public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectional waste. (b) It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. (c) Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.05, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-81. - Sewer service; application requirement, security deposit. The consumer shall make application for water and sewer service in person at the city hall, and at the same time shall make a cash security deposit as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council for sewer service. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.06, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-82. - Connection to public sewer required. (a) Nonconforming houses, buildings or property. (1) Any house, building, or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purpose within the city and located within two miles of a line of public sanitary sewer, shall be deemed nonconforming if such house, building, or property may be connected so that sewage will flow from the house, building, or property and into said sewerage line by gravity, and the house, building, or property is not so connected. (2) Where a house, building, or property deemed to be nonconforming pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section is destroyed or removed and requires replacement, or where the septic system serving the nonconforming house, building, or property fails and cannot be properly repaired, the owner of the nonconforming house, building, or property is hereby required at his or her own expense to install suitable toilet facilities directly with the line of public sanitary sewer, in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 60 days after the date of official notice to do so. A septic system shall be determined to be failing and incapable of proper repair under this section by the city or the Henry County Health Department. (b) New development or construction. The owner of any house, building, or property developed or constructed after the effective date of this article and used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes within the city and located within two miles of a line of public sanitary sewer, now in existence or afterwards constructed, to which such house, building, or property may be connected so that sewage will flow therefrom and into such a sewerage line by gravity, is hereby required at his own expense to install suitable toilet facilities directly with the line of public sanitary sewer, in accordance with the provisions of this article. (c) Appeals. (1) Where the owner of any house, building, or property disagrees with the application of this section because the requirement that the house, building, or property connect to public sanitary sewer creates an undue hardship, said owner has the right to appeal to the mayor and council. An appeal pursuant to this section must be made in writing setting forth the concerns of the owner. An appeal must be filed within five days of the receipt of official notice to connect to public sewer. A hearing on the appeal shall be heard at the next scheduled city council meeting. (2) This appeal process shall not interfere with the rights of the person or entity to seek judicial relief in a court of competent jurisdiction, but shall be exhausted before judicial relief is pursued. Any appeal to the Superior Court of Henry County must be filed within 30 days of the decision of the mayor and city council. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.07, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 242, § 1, 7-11-06) Sec. 86-83. - Building sewers and connections; permit required, application and fees. (a) No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. (b) There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: (1) For residential and commercial service; and (2) For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. (c) In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent to the judgment of the city. A permit and inspection fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.08, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-84. - Connection fees and expense. (a) The owner shall pay the city a standard tap-on fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and city council. (b) All costs and expenses incident to the connection of the building sewer from the owner's building to the city property line shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the connection of the building sewer. Any connection from the city property line into the public sewer shall be made by the city. (c) In addition to the payment of costs and expenses by the owner as provided in this section, the owner shall bear all costs and expenses (labor, materials, etc.) for the construction of sewer from the property line of the owner to the nearest existing sewer line, unless otherwise approved by the mayor and city council. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.09, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-85. - Separate connections for every building. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another or on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.10, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-86. - Use of old building sewers. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings when they are found, on examination and test by the city, to meet all requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 77, § 3.11, 10-12-93) Sec. 86-87. - Construction specifications and requirements. (a) Pipe material specifications. The building sewer shall be cast iron soil pipe; ASTM Specification A74, latest revision, or equal; ductile iron pipe, American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Specification A21.51, latest revision, or equal; or polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe, ASTM Specification D3034, latest revision. (1) All joints shall be tight and waterproof. (2) Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe and ductile iron pipe with bolted mechanical joints. This also may be required by the city where the sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. (3) If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that plastic pipe may be accepted if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the city. (b) Pipe size and slope. The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the city but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-eighth-inch per foot. (c) Elevation, placement, grade. Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to and within three feet of any bearing wall. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipes and fittings. (d) Use of lifts. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewerage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. (e) Excavation, pipelaying and backfill. All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trenchwork unless otherwise approved by the city. Pipelaying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM Specification C12, except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. All open trenchwork shall conform to current requirements of the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA). (f) Joints and connections generally. All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Joint materials and workmanship shall in all cases comply with the pipe manufacturer's recommendations. (g) Connection of building sewer to public sanitary sewer. All work involving connection of building sewers to a public sewer shall be performed by a qualified, experienced sewer contractor, approved by the city. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the Y branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is 12 inches in diameter or less and no properly located Y branch is available, the contractor shall install a Y branch in the public sewer at the location specified by the city. Where the public sewer is greater than 12 inches in diameter and no properly located Y is available, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, which shall enter in the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees. A 45-degree ell may be used to make such connection, with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the city. (h) Connection of sources of surface water runoff to public sanitary sewer. No person shall cause the connection of downspouts, exterior foundation drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer which is in turn connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. (i) Protection of public from hazard during work, restoration of public property after completion of work. Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer: (1) Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit. (2) Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 milligrams per liter of fat, oil or greases or any other substance which may solidify between 32 degrees Fahrenheit and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (0 degrees Celsius and 65 degrees Celsius). (3) Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. (4) Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. (5) Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage works. (6) Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewerage works. (7) Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. (8) Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids or dissolved solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant. (9) Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance. Concentrations of hydrogen sulfide, sulphur dioxide and nitrous dioxide are hereby limited to a maximum of 1.0 milligrams per liter. (10) Any waters containing strong acid, iron-pickling wastes or concentrated plating solutions, whether neutralized or not. (11) Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the city in compliance with state and federal regulations. (12) Any materials which exert or cause excessive discoloration. (13) Any unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting slugs. (14) Any waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other receiving waters. (15) Water or wastes discharged to the public sewer system from the manufacturing process of any industry shall be subject to special and specific review and approval by the city. Sec. 86-131. - Development impact fee act. (a) The state has adopted the "Development Impact Fee Act" or "DIFA" which includes certain requirements for cities regarding the imposition of tap-on or connection fees for water and sewer systems. The city has undertaken a study of both its water and sewer system tap on fees with consideration to such requirements of the Development Impact Fee Act (O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq.). (Ord. No. 77, § 4.01, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 295, § 1, 2-19-08) Sec. 86-132. - Water connection fee. The owner or his agent shall make application for connection to the city's water system on forms furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city. Prior to the connection of any use or building to the city's water system, a fee shall be paid as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (1) Fee. The water tap on fee shall be a nonrefundable connection fee which shall consist of the total of a water system impact fee plus the cost to the city of connecting the building to the water system. The water system impact fee shall be determined from the impact fee schedule on file in the office of the city clerk. For uses not listed in such schedule, the water system impact fee shall be determined by multiplying the per-gallon-per-day fee shown in such schedule times the average daily water consumption of the proposed use in gallons per day. The cost of water connection shall be the actual cost of the connection to the city, including all direct and indirect costs of materials, labor and equipment, as determined by the mayor from time to time. (2) Collection of connection fees. All fees for connection to the water system shall be paid as a prerequisite for approval of such connection to the water system. The following shall control the collection of such fees: a. The city may accept a deposit reflecting the estimated cost to the city of connecting the use to water, pending final determination of actual costs after the work has been completed. b. Fees paid on the basis of the impact fee schedule on file in the office of the city clerk, to which the direct cost of connection has been added, shall be nonrefundable and constitute full and complete payment unless the city determines that the average daily usage exceeds the amount of usage contemplated under the fees set forth in such schedule. If the city determines that the average daily usage exceeds such amount, the city shall bill the owner of the property an additional impact fee, which fee shall be due within 30 days of receipt of such bill. c. Fees calculated on average daily usage basis: 1. For water impact fees proposed to be calculated on the basis of average gallon-per-day usage instead of the impact fee schedule, the applicant shall present credible evidence prepared, certified and sealed by a knowledgeable professional engineer (P.E.) registered in the state acceptable to the city, or other person acceptable to the city, regarding the projected water usage of the proposed use. Such evidence shall be based on other similar uses, historical water usage by the same type of use, engineering calculations based on accepted standards and practices, or other data or procedures acceptable to the city. 2. The payment of an impact fee calculated on the basis of average daily usage may be accepted by the city as a conditional payment, pending actual water usage experienced by the use over a 12-month period of full operation or occupancy. 3. Impact fees paid under the above-stated calculation are nonrefundable. If there is any expansion or increase in the average daily usage, additional impact fees shall be collected by the city based upon the amount of the impact fee that is in existence as of the date of the determination of the expansion or the increased daily usage. The additional fee shall be due within 30 days of receipt of such bill. d. The mayor or his designee shall have the authority to interpret this chapter and the calculation of appropriate connection fees, including both impact fees and direct connection costs to the city. Any aggrieved applicant for connection to the water system may appeal the decision of the mayor to the city council, whose determination shall be final. (Ord. No. 288, § 2, 1-18-08) Sec. 86-135. - Water and sewer connection fee amendments. (a) Short title. This section shall be known as the Water and Sewer Connection Fee Act of 2002. (b) Purpose. The purpose of this section is to regulate the use and development of land so as to assure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of system improvements necessary to provide water and sewer service and facilities in the city. (c) Definitions. For purposes of this section and chapter 86 generally, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: Capital improvement means an improvement with a useful life of ten years or more, by new construction or other action, which increases the service capacity of the water or sewer system. Capital improvements element means that portion of the comprehensive plan, which sets out projected needs for system improvements during a planning horizon established in the comprehensive plan, a schedule of capital improvements that will meet the anticipated need for system improvements, and a description of anticipated funding sources for each required improvement. City means the City of Hampton or its designee. Comprehensive plan means the Henry County/Cities Joint Comprehensive Development Plan. Development impact fee district means the City of Hampton. Project improvements means site improvements and facilities that are planned and designed to provide water or sewer service for a particular development project and that are necessary for the use and convenience for the occupants or users of the project and are not system improvements. The character of the improvement shall control a determination of whether an improvement is a project improvement or system improvement and the physical location of the improvement on-site or off-site shall not be considered determinative of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement. If an improvement or facility provides or will provide more than incidental service or facilities capacity to persons other than users or occupants of a particular project, the improvement or facility is a system improvement and shall not be considered a project improvement. Proportionate share means that portion of the cost of system improvements which is reasonably related to the demands and needs of a project. System improvements means capital improvements that are water facilities, sewage facilities, or other facilities which are designed to provide water and sewage services to the community at large, in contrast to project improvements. System improvement costs means costs incurred to provide additional water or sewer capacity needed to serve new growth and development for planning, design and construction, land acquisition, land improvements, design and engineering related thereto, including the cost of constructing or reconstructing system improvements or facility expansions, including but not limited to the construction contract price, surveying and engineering fees, related land acquisition costs (including land purchases, court award and costs, attorney's fees, and expert witness fees) and expenses incurred for qualified staff or any qualified engineer, planner, architect, landscape architect, or financial consultant for preparing or updating the capital improvement element, and administrative costs equal to three percent of the total amount of the costs. System improvement costs shall also include projected interest charges and other finance costs if and to the development impact fees are to be used for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes, or other financial obligations issued by or on behalf of the city to refinance the capital improvement elements. Such costs do not include routine and periodic maintenance expenditures, personnel training, and other operating costs. (d) Background. The Development Impact Fee Act ("DIFA") of 1990, codified at O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq., and as amended, established certain requirements for municipalities seeking to adopt impact fees. In 1993, the City of Hampton ("city") engaged an urban planning firm to review water and sewer service needs of city residents and to issue a report outlining what type of connection and tap-on fees the city could charge to cover costs associated with providing utility services. The urban planning firm issued a report shortly thereafter ("the 1993 Report"), and the city relied on it in adopting Ordinance No. 77, later codified in chapter 86. These provisions established rules and regulations to govern water and sewer service in the city and impact fees and other costs to be assessed prior to establishment of service. The fees and charges set forth in chapter 86 remained unchanged for several years. In the meantime, however, the city faced tremendous population growth and a dramatic increase in the need for water and sewer service. The city recently responded by engaging another urban planning firm to update the 1993 Report. A revised "Water And Sewer Connection Fee Analysis" was issued in draft form in January of 2002 ("the 2002 report"), and it details the costs associated with providing water and sewer service to new residents in the future. Because the city's current water and sewer system may not be sufficient to provide for future needs of the city, the city intends to rely on the 2002 report in amending the fees and charges set forth in chapter 86. The water and sewer hook up and connection fees referred to in chapter 86 are charged by the city, not a local government authority. Moreover, the capital recovery portion of the new fees (collected for system improvements) to be charged pursuant to this section do not exceed the development's fair proportionate share of those improvements, and the fees are at or below the maximum tap-on fees that could be established by law. Under the circumstances, many of the procedural requirements imposed by DIFA are inapplicable. Nevertheless, the city finds that the comprehensive planning requirements adopted by the state may still be useful as a guide in responding to present and future development needs. (e) Acceptance of 2002 report and adoption of findings. Upon due consideration of the 2002 report, related information and materials on file with the city, and public comments, if any, submitted on the subject and reflected in official city minutes, the city hereby accepts the 2002 report and exhibits, if any, incorporated by reference, and adopts the findings and recommendations contained therein. (f) Imposition of amended connection fees. To the extent that an owner or his agent shall be required to pay a fee or fees pursuant to section 86-132 or section 86-133, the following shall control: (1) Any person who after the effective date of this section seeks to connect to the city's water system or sewer system shall pay an amended connection fee or fees in the manner and amount set forth in this section. (2) No permit for any activity requiring payments of an amended connection fee or fees pursuant to this section shall be issued by the city or its designee unless and until the required fee or fees has been paid. (g) Computation of the amount of connection fees for water and sewer taps. (1) At the option of an owner or his agent, the amount of the connection fees for water and sewer taps shall be those set forth in Table 17 of the 2002 report, a copy of which is incorporated by reference and shall be maintained on file with the city clerk for public inspection. (2) If an owner or agent shall elect not to have the connection fees for water and sewer taps determined according to subsection (g)(1) of this section, then pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-71-4(g) the developer may apply for individual fee determination. A developer applying for an individual fee determination shall prepare and submit to the city manager an individual fee calculation study for the development activity for which a building permit is sought. The individual fee calculation study shall: (i) follow the prescribed methodologies and formats for the study established on page 25 of the 2002 report; or (ii) only to the extent required by state law, and subject to approval by the city, such other professionally accepted methodology that identifies a project's proportionate share. In the event another methodology is utilized, the documentation shall be prepared and presented by qualified professionals in their respective fields and shall follow best professional practices and methodologies. The city shall provide an owner with an individual fee determination consistent with the 2002 report within 30 days after presentation of the individual fee calculation study. (h) Allocation and use of funds. All fees collected pursuant to this chapter shall be properly identified and promptly transferred for deposit into the appropriate fund(s) pursuant to applicable law. Fees shall be used solely for the purposes specified in this chapter. (1) Fees collected pursuant to this section shall be used for system improvements. No funds shall be used for periodic or routine maintenance or for any purpose not in accordance with the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-71-8. (2) Fees shall be used exclusively for system improvements in the development impact fee district in which the project for which the fees were paid is located. (3) Fees shall be expended in the order in which they are collected. (4) Each fiscal period the city manager shall present to the mayor and council an annual report describing the amount of fees collected, encumbered and used during the preceding year allocated to the development impact fee district and any future districts established by the city. Monies, including any accrued interest, not assigned in any fiscal period shall be retained in the same fund until the next fiscal period except as provided elsewhere in this section. (5) The city shall be entitled to retain up to three percent of all fees it collects under this section as an administrative fee to offset the costs of administering this section. (i) Credits. Credits against water and sewer connection fees shall be given as follows: (1) No credit shall be given for project improvements. (2) Credit shall be given for the present value of the construction of improvements or contribution or dedication of land or money by an owner subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives and required or accepted by the city from the owner or his predecessor in title for system improvements (the "post-ordinance credits"). a. A person claiming post-ordinance credits shall submit to the city manager a project description in sufficient detail to allow the city manager to prepare an engineering and construction cost estimate. A person proposing credit for system improvements shall present cost estimates and property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals to be used by the city manager in determining the amount of the credit. All construction must be made in accordance with applicable city, county or state development and design standards. A person proposing post-ordinance credits for land dedication shall present the city manager with property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals and a certified copy of the most recent assessment of the property for tax purposes to be used by the city manager in determining the amount of credit. However, the city manager retains the right to determine the amount to be credited by preparing engineering and construction cost estimates and/or property appraisals for those improvements. b. Post-ordinance credits must be claimed at the time of the application for a permit. any credit not so claimed shall be deemed waived. (j) Refunds. Refunds of connection fees shall be made only in the following instance(s) and in the following manner: (1) Upon application to the city manager by the owner, the city shall refund 97 percent of the fee paid if: (i) capacity is available and service is denied; or (ii) any other basis for a refund exists which is required by state law. The city shall retain three percent of the fee paid as an administrative fee. (2) A refund application shall be made to the city manager within one year from the date such refund becomes payable hereunder. Any refund not applied for within said time period shall be deemed waived. (3) A refund application shall include information and documentation sufficient to permit the city manager to determine whether the refund claimed is proper, and, if so, the amount of such refund. (4) A refund shall include a pro rata share of interest actually earned on the unused or excess development impact fee paid. (5) All refunds shall be paid within 60 days after the city determines that such refund is due. (k) Review of connection fee structure. The connection fee structure shall be reviewed by the mayor and the council annually; provided, however, the failure to review such structure shall not invalidate this section. (l) Penalty and enforcement provisions. A violation of this section shall be a petty offense punishable according to Code section 1-11; however, in addition to or in lieu of any criminal prosecution, the city shall have the power to sue for relief in civil court to enforce the provisions of this section. Knowingly furnishing false information to the city on any matter relating to the administration of this section or chapter 86 shall constitute a violation thereof. (m) Acceptance of 2007 report and adoption of findings. Finding that the current rates for water and sewer connection fees are no longer sufficient to provide for the city's future needs, the city engaged Ross and Associates to prepare a revised "water and sewer connection fee analysis" which was considered and accepted by the city in November 2007 ("the 2007 report"). The 2007 report details the costs associated with providing water and sewer service to new residents of the city. The city hereby adopts the water and sewer installation cost estimate found in Table 28 of the 2007 report, attached to Ordinance No. 295 and incorporated herein by reference as Exhibit "B". A copy of the 2007 report shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk and be available for public inspection. (Ord. No. 133, § 1, 2-12-02; Ord. No. 295, § 2, 2-19-08) Sec. 86-136. - Payment of sewer connection fees for residential dwelling units made prior to October 3, 2006. (2) The reservation of sewer treatment capacity, provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this section, shall last for a period of 365 days from the effective date hereof. (3) An applicant who has made a payment, as provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this section, must secure a building permit to commence the construction of a residential dwelling unit for which payment was made prior to the expiration of the 365-day period established by subsection (a)(2) of this section. (4) If an applicant does not secure a building permit to commence the construction of a residential dwelling unit for which advance payment was made, pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section, prior to the expiration of the 365-day period established by subsection (a)(2) of this section, the applicant's reservation of sewer capacity shall lapse. (5) If an applicant secures a building permit to commence the construction of a residential dwelling unit for which advance payment was made, pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section, prior to the expiration of the 365-day period established by subsection (a)(2) of this section, the applicant's reservation of sewer capacity shall continue for 270 days from the date of the acquisition of a building permit or the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, whichever occurs first. (6) If an applicant secures a building permit to commence the construction of a residential dwelling unit for which payment was made, pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section, prior to the expiration of the 365-day period established by subsection (a)(2) of this section, but a certificate of occupancy is not issued within 270 days from the date of acquisition of the building permit, the applicant's reservation of sewer capacity shall lapse. (b) Payment of sewer connection fees made incidental to obtaining a building permit. (1) The city shall reserve sewer treatment capacity in the amount of 300 gallons per day, per residential dwelling unit, for any applicant who, prior to October 3, 2006, which is the date of the first reading hereof, has made payment to the city for sewer connection for a residential dwelling unit incidental to obtaining a building permit. (2) The reservation of sewer treatment capacity, provided for in subsection (b)(1) of this section, shall last for a period of 270 days from the effective date hereof, or until a certificate of occupancy issues, whichever occurs first. (3) An applicant who has paid for sewer connection for a residential dwelling unit or units prior to October 3, 2006, must secure a certificate of occupancy within the 270-day period provided for by subsection (b)(2). If a certificate of occupancy is not secured for a residential dwelling unit, as provided by subsection (b), within 270 days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives, the reservation of sewer capacity pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section shall lapse. (Ord. No. 189, § 1, 10-12-04; Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Sec. 86-137. - Sewer connection obtained on or after October 3, 2006. (a) When, on or after October 3, 2006, which is the date of the first reading hereof, an applicant obtains a sewer connection at the time of obtaining a building permit, the city shall reserve sewer capacity for the applicant in the amount of 300 gallons per day, per residential dwelling unit. (b) The city shall reserve sewer treatment capacity for an applicant, pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, for a period of 270 days from the date of issuance of a building permit, or until such date as the applicant obtains a certificate of occupancy, whichever occurs first. (c) The applicant must secure a certificate of occupancy within the 270-day time period provided for in subsection (b) of this section. If a certificate of occupancy is not secured within said time period, the reservation of sewer treatment capacity provided for by subsection (a) shall lapse. (Ord. No. 238, § 1, 6-6-06; Ord. No. 238-A, § 2, 8-8-06; Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Sec. 86-138. - Refund. (a) Should an applicant fail to obtain either a building permit, or a certificate of occupancy, or both, within the time limitations prescribed by this article, thereby causing the applicant's reservation of sewer treatment capacity to lapse, the applicant shall be given a refund of the fees paid in advance, except for the fees paid to obtain the building permit. No interest shall be paid upon any fees reimbursed due to a lapse. (b) Upon request, an applicant whose sewer capacity has lapsed for the reasons stated in subsection (a) may choose not to receive a refund of the fees paid in advance. Said funds shall then be credited against the fee rate in place at such time as the applicant obtains a new building permit. (Ord. No. 238, § 1, 6-6-06; Ord. No. 238-A, § 2, 8-8-06; Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Sec. 86-139. - Effect of lapse. An applicant whose sewer capacity reservation lapses, pursuant to this article, forever loses the right to reserve sewer capacity with regard to the residential dwelling units to which said lapse applies. At such time as an applicant's sewer capacity reservation lapses, the applicant is no longer guaranteed sewer treatment capacity with regard to the residential dwelling unit or units for which the application was made. Instead, upon lapse, the city will provide sewer service on a first come, first served basis, after an applicant has complied with all requirements related to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (Ord. No. 238-A, § 4, 8-8-06; Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Sec. 86-140. - Written contract required for the acceptance of advanced payment. No city official or employee is authorized to accept the advanced payment of any utility fees charged by the city without a written contract authorizing such payment. Such a written contract must be prepared by the city attorney and approved by mayor and council prior to execution. (Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Sec. 86-141. - Monthly monitoring by city engineer. The city engineer shall monitor the wastewater treatment capacity of the city and shall provide monthly written reports to the city manager detailing the wastewater treatment capacity available. (Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Sec. 86-142. - Appeal. Any person or legal entity adversely affected by a decision of an employee, official, or agent of the city under this article shall have the right of appeal. Said appeal must be made in writing within ten days of the decision of the city employee, official, or agent and must provide clear notice of the claims being asserted. If a person or legal entity does not comply with the requirements set forth in this section, his or her right to appeal is forever waived. (Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Sec. 86-143. - Electric meter installation and connection fee. The owner, or his agent, shall make application for an electric meter and installation and connection of the meter to the city's electrical system on forms furnished by the city. Said application shall be submitted with any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city. Prior to the installation and connection of any electric meter to the city's electric system, the owner, or his agent, shall pay a fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges, incorporated as Appendix "A", which is on file with the office of the city clerk. Said fees shall, from time to time, be adjusted by ordinance adopted by the mayor and council. (1) Fee. The electric meter installation and connection fee shall be a nonrefundable fee which shall consist of the cost of the meter, materials, labor, and connection to the city's electrical system. Fees shall be applied uniformly within use classifications. Use classifications shall consist of residential, commercial or office/institutional, and industrial/manufacturing. Said fees shall apply to all persons or entities seeking electrical service from the city for new structures as well as any person or entity seeking electrical services from the city for a structure which was remodeled, expanded or otherwise in need of a new meter. Fees shall not apply to structures damaged by acts of God, such as lighting and fire or smoke damage not caused by arson. (2) The property owner shall not own the meter. The city or its designated representative shall install and connect the meter. (3) Any aggrieved applicant for installation and connection of an electric meter under this section may appeal the denial of an application or imposition of the fee to the mayor and city council whose determination shall be final. Any appeal thereafter shall be by writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Henry County. (Ord. No. 254, § 2, 10-10-06) Secs. 86-144—86-160. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - WATER CONSERVATION[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Flow rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, § 18-61 et seq.
Sec. 86-161. - Authorization. From time to time it may become necessary to restrict or curtail water consumption due to drought conditions as required in the county water conservation plan to meet the requirements of the environmental protection division, state department of natural resources. (Ord. No. 1-86, 7-8-86) Sec. 86-162. - Action by mayor. When it becomes necessary to impose bans, restrictions or curtailment of water usage, the mayor shall have the authority to do so and to name those restrictions and the time and duration of such restrictions as defined by priority in the county water conservation plan. (Ord. No. 1-86, 7-8-86) Sec. 86-163. - Penalty for violation. Any consumer who uses water in violation of the restrictions imposed by the mayor and city council will be issued a warning citation for the first offense. Any consumer who is issued a second citation and if found guilty shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 1-86, 7-8-86) Sec. 86-164. - Restriction on outdoor water of landscape. Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining groundcover, trees, shrubs, or other plants may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: (1) Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; (2) Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable city and county ordinances and state guidelines; (3) Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; (4) Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed wastewater; (5) Watering personal food gardens; (6) Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; (7) Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; (8) Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; (9) Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; (10) Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; (11) Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; (12) Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or (13) Hydroseeding. (Ord. No. 351, § 1, 1-4-11) Sec. 86-165. - Enforcement. (a) No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in the ordinance. (b) The city's code enforcement officer shall be the enforcement authority for Ordinance No. 351. The city manager may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement, including the Hampton Police Department. (c) Penalties for violation. Any violation of section 86-164 may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the Hampton Municipal Court, and violators shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 of the City Code. (Ord. No. 351, § 1, 1-4-11) Secs. 86-166—86-170. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - STREET LIGHT DISTRICTS
Sec. 86-171. - Purpose. The purpose of the City of Hampton Street Light Districts Ordinance is to provide for the installation of street lights and a special assessment for lighting expenses for residential districts that are located within the service area of public utilities other than the city electrical service area. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-172. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Applications for street light district. A form approved by and presented to the city for the creation of street light districts in areas outside the limits of the city's own electrical service system which shall contain the following information: (1) List of names, addresses and lot numbers of property owners within the district to be served by the street light system. (2) The utility company which will install and provide the street light service. (3) A map designating the geographical area for the district to be served by the utility company. (4) A street lighting plan for the location and number of street lights to be installed. City. The City of Hampton, Georgia, City Council and/or its authorized designee for the purpose of administering the ordinance from which this article derives. County tax commissioner. The Henry County Tax Commissioner is the designated official responsible for adding special assessment liens to the county property tax bills for street lighting districts within the city, for which the services are provided by electric utility companies other than the City of Hampton. Existing residential area. A residential subdivision or geographical area, which may be identified by legal description, that has been established for more than one year based on recorded plat or plats. Liens. The method by which the county tax commissioner establishes an interest in and to the real property and/or owner thereof for the purposes of collecting funds through the county property tax bill, sufficient to operate the street light districts within the city which are served by other electric utility companies. New residential development. A new residential subdivision within the city which has been approved by the city council as a final plat for building construction, but for which building construction has not commenced through the authorization of building permits. Public hearing. A hearing conducted by the city council to determine whether or not to approve an application to establish a street light district. Rates. The estimated expenses for the operation and maintenance of the street light system within street light districts established by the city. The rate for each property owner within the district may include the amortized expense in initial construction of the street lighting system for the district and/or actual expense for power and maintenance. Special assessment. The amount levied against each property within the street light district assigned to the county property tax bill which each owner must pay to reimburse the city for payments to other electric utility companies serving the street light district. Standards. Lighting standards shall be those approved by the American Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting, sponsored by the Illuminating Engineering Society, as may be applied or amended by the respective electric utility companies which will be serving the street lighting districts established within the city. Street light district. A geographical area within the city limits of the City of Hampton, within which street lights are installed and serviced by electrical utilities other than the city, for the purpose of providing safety, and for which a special assessment is applied to all properties within the district for reimbursement of electric utility expenses paid by the city. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-173. - Procedure. Individuals owning real property in an existing residential area within the city desiring to illuminate the streets in the area where they live or own property may apply to the city to establish a street light district. The application must be supported by a petition signed by not less than 51 percent of the property owners within the area proposed to be established as a street light district. Upon receipt of the application, the city planning and zoning office will contact the utility company serving the area proposed for the street light district to prepare a street lighting plan, showing the number and location of street lights for the district, based on applicable standards referred to in this article. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-174. - Hearing. Upon application being made, the city shall conduct an investigation for establishing a street light district based on the lighting plan prepared by the respective utility company and rates determined for property assessment. A report from the planning and zoning department shall be forwarded to the city manager, who in turn shall place the application on the next convenient agenda for a public hearing at a regularly scheduled city council meeting. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-175. - New residential development. (a) Developers of new residential subdivisions shall make applications to the city to install street lights with underground wiring. It shall be the responsibility of the developer to coordinate the installation of the street lights with the respective utility company and the city public works department consistent with the standards referred to in this article. (b) The developer shall present an application for the street light district, along with the lighting plan from the utility company, to the planning and zoning department. A report from the planning and zoning department shall be forwarded to the city manager who in turn shall present it to the mayor and city council as part of the information presented for approval of a final subdivision plat. (c) This section shall apply to subdivisions for which a final plat has been approved, construction of dwellings is underway, and for which certificates of occupancy have been issued. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-176. - City-initiated street lighting district. (a) The city council on its own action may initiate a street light district application for any area of the city which is not within the city's electrical service area but for which the city is being charged or will be charged for electrical service by the electric utility company servicing the area encompassing the proposed street lighting district. (b) At a properly noticed public hearing, and upon posting a public hearing notice sign at the property and written notice to property owners 15 days prior to the hearing, the city council may approve the street lighting district, and the city manager will then notify the tax commissioner to apply special assessment for each property to pay as part of the county's annual ad valorem property tax bill. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-177. - Assessments. Each property owner, for either an existing residential area or new residential development, for which street light districts have been authorized by the city council, shall be required to pay a special assessment rate levied on each property. This assessment shall be each property owner's pro-rata share of the total charge for annual lighting within the district. Unit cost of street lighting charges shall be based on fees provided by electric utility companies for both overhead and underground installation. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-178. - Charges and imposition of liens. The rates or charges for street light services shall constitute a special assessment on each property served. Those special assessments shall be added to the property owners county ad valorem property tax bills at the end of each year and shall constitute a lien on the property. Said liens shall have the same priority as tax assessments, and an execution may issue for the purposes of enforcing the lien including foreclosure and or judicial sale. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Sec. 86-179. - Compliance with standards. The construction and installation of any light system for a street light district shall comply strictly with those standards defined above. (Ord. No. 284, § 1, 11-13-07) Secs. 86-180—86-189. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM
Sec. 86-190. - Short title. This article shall be known as the "Identity theft prevention program". (Ord. No. 318, § 1, 12-2-08) Sec. 86-191. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to comply with 16 CFR § 681.2 in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. (Ord. No. 318, § 1, 12-2-08) Sec. 86-192. - Definitions. For purposes of this article, the following definitions apply: City means the City of Hampton. Covered account means: (1) An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account or savings account; and (2) Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation or litigation risks. Credit means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payments therefore. Creditor means any person who regularly extends, renews or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies.
